title: Meta-analysis: Condorcet Jury Theorem vs portfolio theory for spawn diversification
method: Regime analysis across 17 F-FIN1 experimental runs (S182-S186). Filtered to n>=10 trials for stability. Compared observed N=3 majority vote accuracy against Condorcet Jury Theorem (CJT) prediction and portfolio variance reduction theory.

findings.model_correction: F-FIN1 was framed as portfolio diversification (linear aggregation: Var(mean)=sigma^2/N). The correct model is Condorcet Jury Theorem (CJT) because majority vote is NONLINEAR aggregation. CJT predicts: P(majority correct at N=3) = 3p^2(1-p) + p^3, with p=0.5 as critical threshold.

condorcet_threshold.above_0.5: Majority vote IMPROVES accuracy. At p=0.8, CJT predicts 89.6% (+9.6pp gain).
condorcet_threshold.below_0.5: Majority vote DEGRADES accuracy. At p=0.2, CJT predicts 10.4% (-9.6pp loss).
condorcet_threshold.at_0.5: Neutral — no effect from adding agents.
condorcet_threshold.connection_to_B-FIN2: Below-threshold performance is SYSTEMATIC risk (B-FIN2). Adding agents amplifies the error. Fix the individual agent first.

correlation_effect.derivation: From avg variance ratio 0.747: Var(portfolio) = (1/N)[1 + (N-1)rho] * Var(ind). 0.747 = (1/3)(1 + 2*0.621).
correlation_effect.effect: Correlation dampens both help (above threshold) and hurt (below threshold). Observed N3 accuracy is CLOSER to N1 accuracy than CJT predicts in both regimes. Correlation makes majority vote conservative.

variance_reduction.note: Variance reduction is REAL and separate from mean effect. Portfolio theory's sigma^2/N applies to trial-level accuracy variance, even though the per-question aggregation is nonlinear. Signal extraction quality (direct vs resolver) matters more than accuracy level.

findings.regime_boundary: p=0.5 per-question accuracy. This is the Condorcet threshold. Below this, spawning more agents for majority vote HURTS. Above, it helps. The swarm analogy: only parallelize tasks where individual agents are better than random.
findings.benchmark_saturation: The rerun20b run (100% accuracy both N=1 and N=3) proves the benchmark is too easy after false-positive hardening. At saturation, diversification is meaningless — all agents agree on the right answer. Future tests need accuracy in the 0.4-0.7 range to observe both CJT effects.

cross_domain.iso_new: ISO-14 (Condorcet Jury Theorem): nonlinear vote aggregation amplifies above-chance competence, degrades below-chance. Connects to ISO-2 (selection), ISO-4 (phase transition at p=0.5), ISO-5 (amplifying feedback in both directions).
cross_domain.swarm_implication: Spawn parallel agents only when individual accuracy > 0.5 for the task. Below 0.5 = systematic error = fix CORE beliefs/tools first (B-FIN2). The p=0.5 threshold IS the spawn/fix decision boundary from P-119.
cross_domain.principle_candidate: P-NNN: Majority-vote diversification has a competence threshold at p=0.5 — above it amplifies accuracy, below it amplifies error. Test individual accuracy before spawning.

verdict.evidence_quality: Meta-analysis of 17 runs, 6 filtered (n>=10). CJT predictions match direction in all cases. Correlation effect (rho=0.62) explains magnitude discrepancies.
verdict.f-fin1_next: Need accuracy-calibrated benchmark (p in 0.4-0.7) to measure CJT gain precisely. Current benchmarks are either too easy (saturated) or too hard (p<0.3). Target the zone where CJT predicts maximum gain: p=0.7-0.8 (gain +7-10pp at N=3).
